meta.cite: Oxford English Dictionary API, Oxford University Press, 0.0.0.0/oed/api/v0.2/word/machine_nn01/senses/?offset=0&limit=10000 . Accessed 18 September 2020

data.definition: A material or immaterial structure, esp. the fabric of the world or of the universe; a construction or edifice. Now rare.
A military engine or siege-tower. Cf. war machine n. (a) at  war n.1 compounds 4. Now historical.
spec. A scheme or plot. Obsolete.
A living body, esp. the human body considered in general or individually. Now chiefly figurative from sense 6b (cf. sense 8b).

notes: In early use predominantly a ‘flying’ car along with the mechanism used to lower it to the stage, often as the climax of a production.
data.definition: Theatre. A (usually movable) contrivance for the production of stage-effects; (in plural) stage machinery. Also figurative. Cf. god from the machine at  god n. int.phrases 4e and deus ex machina n. Now historical and poetic.
A ship or other vessel. Now colloquial: a boat.
In general use: an apparatus, device, instrument, or implement (now archaic and Canadian regional (Newfoundland)); an appliance; a vending machine. Cf. sense 6c.

notes: In 19th- and early 20th-cent. use, the word tended to be applied to devices performing, (relatively) independently of the strength or skill of the operator, work that had formerly been done by hand. Its use has been extended to devices that perform tasks which previously required human mental activity.
data.definition: A complex device, consisting of a number of interrelated parts, each having a definite function, together applying, using, or generating mechanical or (later) electrical power to perform a certain kind of work (often specified by a preceding verbal noun).
In literature, etc.: a contrivance for the sake of effect; a supernatural agency, personage, or incident introduced into a narrative; the interposition of one of these. Now rare.
figurative in general use.

figurative. A living being considered to move or act automatically or mechanically, rather than of its own volition; esp. a person who acts mechanically or unthinkingly, as from habit or obedience; a person who acts with mechanical precision or efficiency. Also: a system or organization of an impersonal or inflexible character.

A (usually wheeled) vehicle or conveyance, esp. one drawn by a horse or horses, or other draught animal or animals. Formerly esp.: a stagecoach or mail coach; (also) a brake, trap, or small carriage (chiefly Scottish). Now historical.

notes: simple, compound machine: see the first element.
data.definition: Mechanics. Anything that transmits force or directs its application.
slang. The penis; the female genitals (rare). Also: †a condom (obsolete).
= bathing-machine n. at  bathing n. compounds . Obsolete.

Used contextually for the particular kind of machine which the speaker or writer intends, as: a sewing machine; a printing machine or mechanical printing press; a shearing-machine (Australian and New Zealand); a typewriter; a calculating machine or computer; a slot machine; a washing machine; etc. Cf. sense 6a.
A bicycle or tricycle; a motorcycle. Formerly also: a dandy-horse or velocipede (now historical).
U.S. colloquial. A fire engine. Obsolete.

notes: party, propaganda, war machine: see the first element.
data.definition: Originally U.S. The controlling organization of a political party or similar body; any organization or group displaying impressive or ruthless efficiency.
A box or case in which fresh fish are sold wholesale. Cf. trunk n. 8b. Obsolete.
Australian and New Zealand colloquial. A totalizator.
An aircraft or airship. Cf. sense 6b.
Originally and chiefly U.S. A motor vehicle, esp. a car.
Painting. A painting of large size, esp. one whose subject matter and composition are complicated, contrived, or exaggerated.
figurative.machine for living (in): a house or other habitation considered as a functional entity. Also in imitative phrases.
A conceptual, abstract, or theoretical mechanism or device; spec. a model or a mathematical abstraction of an existing or hypothetical computer. Cf. Turing machine n.
